bestBHT.bht: The speaker's connection to Saul, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, is highlighted in the mention of his name and tribe. Josephus agrees with the attributed length of Saul's reign, spanning forty years. The people's desire for a king, tired of the theocracy, led to Saul being given to them by God. Despite Saul's sinful actions, Paul proudly acknowledges Benjamin as Saul's tribe. While the Old Testament does not specify the length of his reign, both Josephus and the apostle assign forty years to him.

Henry Alford: It may be not altogether irrelevant to notice that a Saul, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, was speaking; and to trace in this minute specification something characteristic and natural.
Biscoe has well shewn, that as Saul was a young man when anointed king, and Ishbosheth his youngest son was forty years old at his death, his reign cannot have been much short of that period.
It is clearly against the construction to suppose Samuel’s time as well as Saul’s included in the forty years, following as they do upon the verb 'gave them.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: God gave . . . them Saul . . . of the tribe of Benjamin.
That the speaker was himself of the same name and of the same tribe.
With this length of Saul's reign, JOSEPHUS coincides.
Albert Barnes: And afterward they desired a king."
Saul, the son of Cis - is the Greek mode of writing the Hebrew name Kish.
By the space of forty years - During forty years.
John Calvin: But the stability of the election saved them from being punished as such madness did deserve.
The wicked and unlawful desire of the people was to God a new and incredible occasion to erect the kingdom whence Christ should afterward come.
God, who knows how to use evil things well, turned that offense into safety.
Philip Schaff: The Old Testament does not mention the length of Saul’s reign.
The statement here, however, agrees with Josephus, who speaks of Saul reigning eighteen years before Samuel’s death and twenty-two after it.
The Old Testament does not mention the length of Saul’s reign. The statement here, however, agrees with Josephus.
Archibald T. Robertson: They were tired of a theocracy."
Paul mentions with pride that Benjamin was the tribe of Saul, but he does not allude to Saul's sin.
Not in the O.T., but in Josephus, Ant. VI. 14, 9.
John Gill: The Jews are very much divided about the years of Saul's reign, some allow him but two years, and others three.
Our apostle ascribes forty years to him, which must be understood both of him and Samuel, with which Josephus agrees.

That Saul must reign more years than these, and even as many as the apostle assigns to him, may be concluded, not only from his wars with many nations, and his long persecution of David, but from the number of high priests which were in his time.
John Wesley: He gave them Saul forty years — Including the time wherein Samuel judged Israel.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Acts 13:21, the speaker highlights the significance of Saul, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, speaking about the past. Josephus confirms the length of Saul's reign, which aligns with the statement made. It is evident that the people were tired of the theocracy and desired a king, resulting in Saul being given to them by God. While Saul's reign was marked by sin, Paul takes pride in mentioning Benjamin as Saul's tribe. The Old Testament does not mention the length of Saul's reign, but Josephus and the apostle attribute forty years to him.

The speaker's emphasis on Saul, from the tribe of Benjamin, speaking about the past reflects their natural connection. Josephus confirms the length of Saul's reign mentioned here, aligning with the apostle's statement. The people desired a king, leading God to give them Saul. Although Saul's reign was marred by sin, Paul takes pride in his Benjaminite heritage. The exact duration of Saul's reign is debated, but Josephus and the apostle assign forty years to him, suggesting a lengthy rule.

The speaker's connection to Saul, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, is highlighted in the mention of his name and tribe. Josephus agrees with the attributed length of Saul's reign, spanning forty years. The people's desire for a king, tired of the theocracy, led to Saul being given to them by God. Despite Saul's sinful actions, Paul proudly acknowledges Benjamin as Saul's tribe. While the Old Testament does not specify the length of his reign, both Josephus and the apostle assign forty years to him.

The speaker's connection to Saul, a Benjaminite, is emphasized, along with Josephus' agreement on the length of his reign. The people's desire for a king resulted in God giving them Saul. Paul acknowledges Benjamin as Saul's tribe while omitting his sins. Although the Old Testament does not mention the length of his reign, the apostle assigns forty years to Saul, which aligns with Josephus' account. Saul's reign was a fulfillment of the people's desire for a new kingdom, ultimately leading to the coming of Christ.

The speaker's emphasis on Saul being from the tribe of Benjamin reflects something characteristic and natural. Josephus agrees with the mentioned duration of Saul's reign, aligning with the apostle's statement. The people desired a king after being tired of the theocracy, leading God to give them Saul. Despite Saul's sin, Paul takes pride in mentioning Benjamin as Saul's tribe. While the Old Testament does not specify the length of Saul's reign, both Josephus and the apostle assign forty years to him.
